content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is fun, simple (in the right sense of the word) and efficient. I like it ! :D

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is very well thought out and well executed. Also, the Idea is cool. I'd like to make something like it.
Hi there, I like the Idea immensely! Very cool.

Please add in the "constraints" section the fact that there is always at least one digit in the string, otherwise people like me will wonder what to output if y is 0 :-) (I know it is in Test 3/Validator 3, but usually you don't have the time to read the tests as long as they work ^^)
Why not activating the "reverse" mode by the way? I'm sure it's doable given the hints in the tests.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy and fun to solve.
If you truncate instead of rounding (x*100//y), every test passes, but not Validator 1.

Goal
* Please format "string", "x", "y" as {{constants}}.

* Please do not format "being the number of letters" and "being the number of digits" as {{constants}}.

* You may format "number of letters" and "number of digits" in <<bold>>.

* Please change "check" to "calculate" (twice).

* Please change "per digits" to "per digit".

Output
* Please change "letter" to "letters".

* Please change "digits" to "digit".

Cases
* Please change Validator 4 to be similiar to Test 4.

Title
* Please change "digits" to "digit".

Thanks.
Hello! Thanks for the recommendations, just got done changing everything. Can you check it out now?
Hello! Thanks for noticing that, I didn't think about that specific case. Fixed! Can you check it out again?

Hello! I thought about adding that in the constraints area but since it's in one of the tests + the name of the test is a huge hint, I thought of not adding it. But since, there's the possibility of this CoC being the in the fastest mode, maybe it's better to have it there than just in the tests. Therefore, I made that change. Also, the reverse mode thing might be a good idea but I'm not sure if people would understand the tests and the concept behind it. It's hard to tell what the % is about. Let me know if you still think that is possible. Also, can you please upvote so that other people see it? Thanks for the input!

Oops, I've made a mistake in my comment. The following is the correct version (the other changes you've made are fine):

Goal
* Please format "x", "y" as [[variables]] (twice for x and twice for y).

* Please change "{{string}}" to "string [[S]]".

Input
* Please change "string" to "string [[S]]".

Constraints
* Please change "{{string}}" to "[[S]]".

Sorry about that.

Hello again! No problem about that mistakes, everyone does them lol. I've changed everything you asked for. Although I don't agree with changing {{x*100/y}} to [[x]]*100/[[y]] or even {{[[x]]*100/[[y]]}} cause it just looks wrong. May you see if it's all good now? Thanks.
It isn't a matter of appearance; it's a matter of what x and y really are. They are variables, so it's better that they're formatted as such.
